p.s: The two lovers speak about their love against all odds at night in the CapuletsCapulet's garden.
Their language used gives more insight in their feelings towards each other.
To begin with, Romeo argues why he undertook such a risk for seeing Juliet.
He speaks of love here as light wings(l. 66) that help him lean over the wall into the garden.
This metaphor accentuates that his love for Juliet makes him overcome every obstacle; nothing can come between them.
To that, he adds another metaphor, speaking of stony limits(l. 67) being representative here for the orchard's wall.
These limits(l. 67) cannot hold love out (l. 67) which underlines that he is very much in love and that this love cannot be stopped by anything.

However, he seems to be well aware of the danger he is in but argues that there lies morme peril in thine eye than twenty of their swords (ll. 71f) meaning that the act of being with her is more thrilling and dangerous than being discovered.
This comparison emphasizes that her, simply just existing is more dangerous for him than the Capulet's guards.
Their love makes him proof against their enmity(l. 73).
Furthermore into their conversation Romeo applies another metaphor which again stresses and expresses very strongly how much he would do out of love for Juliet.
Making use of this metaphor comparing her to a vast shore (l. 85) and a far [...] sea (l. 80) he undoubtedly lets the readers know of his intention and attitude towards his love for Juliet.

This can be connected to the previous metaphor underyling the power of love that made him on the one hand overcome the orchards wall and on the other hand adventure for such merchandise (l. 84), no matter how far they're apart.
Consequently with the help of this metaphor the readers are constantly reminded of the power of their love.
Yet, Juliet seems to have some concerns about their love against all odds which she expresses in her monologue from lines 85-106.
This shows that she doubts his love for her, which becomes even more clear when asking Dost thou love me?(l. 90).
Her uncertainty and fear are langauge-wise illustrated by an exclamation: O gentle Romeo (l. 93).
This exclamation results in the reader comprehending how much she is torn by contradicting feelings for Romeo since they come from rivaling families.
Nevertheless the imagery of the night used by her beforehand (ll. 85f) revealreveals that she is also in love with him, since then ight covers up her red cheeks.
Both of the two lovers reflect differently on their love for each other: Whilewhile Romeo seems to be very sure, Juliet is a little more hesitant.
Her restraint and seemingly reserved manner becomes evident agin when she repeats that Romeo needs to assure her that he sincerely loves her (ll. 93ff).
This use of repetition gives her concerns more weight and also gives the readers another perspective on the different manner they reflect on their love.

Her inner conflict between breaking with conventions and giving in into her love with Romeo is especially visible as she exclaims that she is willing to farewell compliment (l. 89) yet this is followed by doubts again.
Still, the readers learn at the end of her monologue that despite all her concerns she is too fond (l. 98) and finally decides to put all her concerns aside.
Juliet wants their love to last that is why the imagery and choice of words stemingstemming from the field of night and heaven becomes of importance.
She does not want him to swear [...] by the inconstant moon (l. 104) but by his gracious self (l. 114).
This underlines that since the moon is only to be seen inconsistently, using this to swear by would be not enough for her - she wants their love to come from Romeo and be everlasting.
Elaborating on the moon's changes in her circled orb (l. 110) is an imagery to illustrate that she does not want to bind their love to earthly passings and conventions.

As mentioned above, the imagery of nights plays a crucial role in this scene because it on the one hand hide[s] (l. 75) Romeo from being discovered by Capulet servants and on the other hand adds to the thrilling, romantic atmosphere prevailing in the scene.
The choice of words used by the lovers stems mainly from the field of love, danger and death.
Romeo using frequently the word love (l. 67) or ended (l. 77) underscores that he is willing to die in the attempt of being together with his love Juliet.
Juliet's attitude towards their love against all odds is marked by words expressing doubts and denial such as deny (l. 88), dwell (l. 88) or prove false (l. 92).
To conclude it can be said that the two lovers reflect on their love differently.
Romeo is more straight-forwardstraightforward expressing his strong feelings for Juliet and assuring her multiple times that he's willing to die for her using several metaphors.

Juliet on the other hand is at first more hesitant, reserved and doubts the sincerity of his feelings which is conveyed by her exclaiming her being torn and making allusions, and posing theoretical questions.
Yet at the end of the scene both of them come to admit that they wants to take the risk of breaking conventions and rather be dead and together than being seperated from each other.
The night imagery is here a useful element as it enables them to have this conversation.
Love is perceived by them as something that overcomes every obstacle and convention imposed on them by their families.
